perturbation.original_text: This Agreement, including its attachment and order acknowledgments under the Agreement, constitutes the entire agreement between Distributor and NETGEAR with respect to the purchase, resale and distribution of the Products and is governed by the laws of the State of California except that body of law dealing with conflicts of law.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement, including its attachment and order acknowledgments under the Agreement, constitutes the entire agreement between Distributor and NETGEAR with respect to the purchase, resale and distribution of the Products and will be arbitrated in Delaware, subject to NETGEAR's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text mandates arbitration in Delaware, potentially overriding California laws that protect distributors. This conflicts with California's strong public policy favoring judicial remedies and may violate laws governing the enforceability of arbitration clauses, especially concerning fairness and impartiality. Furthermore, giving NETGEAR sole discretion over the arbitration venue and process introduces bias, conflicting with principles of neutrality and fairness required by California law in arbitration agreements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Arbitration Act, California Franchise Relations Act, Principles of Contract Law regarding fairness and impartiality

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement may not be assigned by either party without prior written permission from the other party, which permission shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempt by either party to assign any right, or delegate any duty or obligation which arises under the Agreement without such permission will be voidable.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement may be freely assigned by NETGEAR to any subsidiary or affiliate without prior notice or consent from Distributor. Distributor may not assign this Agreement under any circumstances.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an imbalance in assignment rights, favoring NETGEAR significantly. Such unilateral assignment clauses can be deemed unconscionable and unenforceable under California law if they unduly burden one party. California courts scrutinize contracts for fairness, and a provision that completely prohibits one party from assigning while allowing the other to do so freely is likely to be challenged, especially if the assignment negatively impacts the Distributor. This conflicts with principles of good faith and fair dealing implied in every contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Contract Law - Unconscionability, Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: Neither party is liable for its failure or delay to perform its obligations under the Agreement due to strikes, wars, revolutions, acts of terrorism, fires, floods, explosions, earthquakes, shortages in labor, components or materials, government regulations, or other causes beyond its control.
perturbation.changed_text: NETGEAR is not liable for any failure or delay to perform its obligations under the Agreement, regardless of cause. Distributor remains fully liable for all obligations.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause provides a mutual force majeure protection. The modified clause removes force majeure protection for NETGEAR while keeping Distributor fully liable regardless of circumstances. This creates a highly unbalanced situation where NETGEAR is shielded from liability even for events within its control, potentially violating principles of good faith and fair dealing under California contract law. Such a one-sided clause may be deemed unconscionable or unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing, Unconscionability
